The average since 2010 is just 7.2, with only five renewals attracting fields of 8+ runners. That has to be a concern, both for the King George and the sport. There are many reasons for this, of course, but the super-saturation of racing has to be a major contributing factor.

Here‚Äôs the average field size for each decade in the last 50 years:

1970-79: 10 runners
1980-89: 9.5 runners
1990-99: 9.6 runners
2000-09: 9.3 runners
2010-19: 8 runners 

So relatively consistent until 2010, which is in line with the wider trends in racing over the same period.

It has been a regular feature of the King George over the years, with only 21 of the last 50 runnings having double digit fields. However, there have only been three renewals with 10+ runners since 2006, so recent trends are more concerning.

A small, select field in the King George is not necessarily indicative of a crisis in racing. All of these legends beat six or fewer rivals in the race:

1970 - Nijinsky
1979 - Troy
1981 - Shergar
1989 - Nashwan
1995 - Lammtarra
2000 - Monjeu
2006 - Hurricane Run
2010 - Harbinger

All five of them were devoid of ideas, any practical policies that could get us out of this post-Brexit, post-Covid cost-of-living crisis and save a country in chaos. Just more meaningless sound bites and not a single sign that they have a clue what to do about it.

Watching the faces of the audience at the leadership debate last night was very telling. The life was literally draining from them, with the dawning realisation that this country is well and truly up sh*t creek without a paddle, no matter who wins the contest.

Add in the secondary spend on food & drink and clearly these are going to be profitable days for racecourses. Presumably the argument is these cross subsidise the ‚Äònormal‚Äô racedays with lower attendance. But that does seem to be a false economy for the future health of the sport.

I would love to know how many first time attendees are repeat visitors. And, more importantly, how many regular racing fans stay away because they are being priced out of the market. The two types of crowd seem increasingly incompatible to me.

Most of these dates are already sold out, so there‚Äôs clearly a demand. And top music concert tickets *are* expensive. But it does beg the question as to whether these days actually deliver on the original concept, which was to bring a new audience into racing.

Very impressive win for Desert Crown in the Derby, to give Sir Michael Stoute his sixth win in the race, 12 years after the last, Workforce in 2010. Shergar, Shahrastani, Kris Kin and North Light complete his six of the best.
Should also have mentioned the Dee Stakes (Star Of India), which has produced two winners of the Derby, Oath (1999) and Kris Kin (2003).

@andrew_patey Slightly biased as I backed the front two at bigger odds before they won their respective trials. Desert Crown looks the most likely winner after his Dante success, but Stone Age was equally impressive in the Derrinstown. Boring, but I think that the fav will win.

No horse has won from as wide as Changingoftheguard (16) in the last 30 years, although Erhaab and Sinndar both won from 15, while High Rise, Authorized and Wings of Eagles were drawn 14. Royal Patronage (1) and Westover (2) have that difficult inside draw to overcome.

Sea The Stars, Kris Kin and Dr Devious all won from stall 4 (Stone Age today), while Motivator and Camelot won from stall 5 (Nations Pride). Stall 7 (Piz Badile) has also been successful three times since 1995 with Lammtarra, Pour Moi and Anthony Van Dyck.

Adayar won the Derby from stall 1 last year, but was the first to do so since Oath in 1999. Ten of the previous 11 winners since 2010 were drawn 7 or higher. Four of them were in double figures, with Australia winning from the same berth as Desert Crown (stall 12).

Aidan O‚ÄôBrien followed the Derrinstown path to the Derby with Galileo and High Chaparral, but his most recent successes have come from the Chester Vase and Lingfield Derby Trial. The latter race has had a resurgence recently, producing two of the last three Epsom winners.

Dante remains the best pointer for Epsom, producing seven winners in the last 30 years; Erhaab, Benny The Dip, North Light, Motivator, Authorized, Workforce (2nd) and Golden Horn. Two of those were trained by Sir Michael Stoute, who is following the same route with Desert Crown.

Record of Derby trials:

Sandown Classic (Westover) - 4 wins, most recent Sharastani 1986 (Benny The Dip 2nd 1997, Adayar 2nd 2021)

Derrinstown (Stone Age) - 3 wins, most recent High Chaparral, 2002

Ballysax (Piz Badile) - 3 wins, most recent Harzand, 2016

Record of Derby trials:

Dante (Desert Crown) 10 wins, most recent Golden Horn 2015

Lingfield (Walk Of Stars 2nd) 9 wins, most recent Anthony Van Dyck 2019 (Adayar 2nd 2021)

Chester Vase (Changingoftheguard) 4 wins, most recent Ruler of the World 2013 (Wing of Eagles 2nd 2017)

Golden Horn was the last Dante winner to land the Derby in 2015 and also the last winning favourite. Since then we‚Äôve had winners at 40/1, 25/1 and 16/1 twice, with none shorter than 13/2. Will another upset be on the cards‚Ä¶? Who will beat Desert Crown and Stone Age‚Ä¶?

Frankie will now finish his racing career on a high. It could so easily have gone sour - and in those dark times it did look like it would end that way. But how you deal with adversity marks the true measure of a man. And that‚Äôs what makes the #Dettori documentary so fascinating.

Ultimately it has always been about Frankie‚Äôs tremendous ability in the saddle. As a jockey he‚Äôs simply one of the best. So many wonderful memories too; Markofdistinction, Balanchine, Lochsong, Magnificent Seven, Dubai Millennium, Authorized, Golden Horn, Stradivarius, Enable.

Frankie‚Äôs always been a far more complex character than his bubbly public persona, and I‚Äôve seen both sides of that too, but in this documentary there was real honesty and self-reflection, which made the redemptive narrative arc of his career all the more interesting & rewarding.

It‚Äôs easy to forget all of the trials and tribulations he‚Äôs endured; from his tumultuous relationship with his father, to that awful plane crash, two drug scandals and various professional fall-outs. Often self-inflicted crises of course, but those character flaws make him human.

I‚Äôve always had an affinity with Frankie: we‚Äôre the same age and I started my involvement in racing the season that he was Champion Apprentice. Our paths have crossed many times over the years, at the Tote & Ascot, and he joined in my 29th birthday celebrations in Dubai. #Dettori

Frankie is engaging and charismatic, as always, but there was a real emotional depth to this documentary, often quite raw, which made it feel far more genuine than the usual glossy glamour that is portrayed in most autobiographical career retrospectives of this nature. #Dettori

Finally saw #Dettori on Sky last night and I have to say it‚Äôs one of the best sport documentaries I‚Äôve seen, not just for horse racing. Refreshingly candid, it provides a real insight into the rollercoaster life and career of @FrankieDettori, charting so many highs and lows.

That still enables us to discount the top half of the handicap, with 12 horses set to carry 11st 1lb or more, including the favourite Gaillard du Mesnil, with the winner more likely to come from the group at the bottom half from 15-30.

Like the Grand National at Aintree, this race tends to attract a classier type of horse these days with more running in the top half of the handicap. The bottom weight in today‚Äôs race is 10st 5lb and lowest rated horse is 137. So you need to allow extra 5lb+ on ratings.

Other key trends: 21/25 winners were officially rated 137 or lower, while 20/25 had finished in the first four in one of their last two starts. But again stamina is the key to this marathon contest with 21/25 having won over three miles or further. #IrishGrandNational

Novices have a good record in the #IrishGrandNational. 21/25 winners were aged between 7 and 10, but the bias is definitely for younger horses: the record is 2 x 6yo, 8 x 7yo, 6 x 8yo, 5 x 9yo, 3 x 10yo, 1 x 11yo since 1996. The last seven winners were all aged in single figures.

Bobbyjo on 11-3, Timbera on 10-12 and Shutthefrontdoor on 10-13 were also exceptions, otherwise 20 of the last 25 winners of the Irish National have actually carried 10st 8lb or less. 17/24 were on 10st 6lb or less. So you need to focus on those at the bottom end of the handicap.

Today‚Äôs #IrishGrandNational is the last of the staying chases this season. Once again the trends show that you need to go for a lightly weighted horse. Our Duke won off 11st 4lb in 2017 but that was only the second winner over 10st 13lb since Commanche Court won the race in 2000.

Significantly, 12 of the last 15 winners of the Grand National had previously finished 1st or 2nd over at least 3m 3.5f. 2016 - First five had all finished 1st or 2nd over 3m 5f+
2017 - First six had all won or been runner up over 3m 4.5f+
2018 - Five of first six had won or placed over 3m 2.5f+ (three over 3m 5f+)

Otherwise, proven stamina has still been the common denominator, even since the race conditions changed in 2013:

The 2001 Grand National result was an exception in many respects, with the 1st & 2nd unproven over distances of over 3m. @notooshabby Having said that, I would always side with the lighter weight horses in any of these marathon contests and some of my main hopes are towards the bottom of the handicap; Mighty Thunder, Cloth Cap and Snow Leopardess. Weight and stamina still remain the main considerations for me.

@notooshabby Good point. The fact that this is universal to all runners lessens the impact, although carrying large weights over distance - particularly on softish ground - is always going to be tiring. But with only 17lb separating the field it‚Äôs perhaps not as significant as previous years.

No less than 36 of the 40 runners are aged ten or under. Snow Leopardess and Any Second Now fly the flag for ten year olds, but otherwise most in this age group are rank outsiders. Eight of the first ten in the betting are 8 or 9, so it‚Äôs set to be another one for the youngsters. https://t.co/dfm5qNEe7Q

There are also only two 11 year olds set to contend this year‚Äôs race; Brahma Bull and Death Duty. There was a recent run for this age group between 2012 & 2014, with Neptune Collonges, Auroras Encore and Pineau De Re all victorious at 11, but they are the only three since 2001. https://t.co/rSo0ASIpFb

At the other end of the age scale, there are far fewer veterans now contesting the race, with only Anibale Fly (aged 12) & Blaklion (13yo) representing older horses. Both have run well in the Grand National previously, finishing 4th, but only two 12 year olds have won since 1990. https://t.co/UUBUYTwpu4

Mighty Thunder won last year‚Äôs Scottish National for Lucinda Russell, while Snow Leopardess took well to the Aintree fences when winning the Becher Chase earlier this season, so you would hope that they still have sufficient experience for this race. https://t.co/l3MHH0kn1y

Mount Ida (8 chase runs), Longhouse Poet (6), Escaria Ten (7), Noble Yeats (7) and Phoenix Way (7) all lack the pre-requisite experience for a National winner, while even Court Maid, Mighty Thunder and Snow Leopardess fall short on chase outings with only nine runs each. https://t.co/OOljGNH39g

With four winners in six years, it‚Äôs perhaps no surprise to see more eight year olds now contesting the race. This age group makes up almost a quarter of the field for the 2022 renewal, so the amount of chasing experience will be a key determining factor for these nine horses. https://t.co/xdyiQBoc8e

In the forty year period between 1974 & 2014 only three 8yo‚Äôs won the race; Corbiere, Party Politics & Bindaree. Yet since the fences were softened we‚Äôve had a run of younger winners, with Many Clouds, One For Arthur, Tiger Roll & Minella Times all successful for this age group. https://t.co/W8O5T6NJ0g

It is this experience over fences that is the key consideration. Every winner since 1990 had at least ten chase runs under their belts. Nine of the last eleven winners had between 10 and 20 chase outings before tackling the Grand National fences. https://t.co/r4UVn1f07e

No seven year old has won the Grand National since Bogskar in 1940, while Mr What was the last novice to win in 1958. This will count against the two seven year olds due to line up in this year‚Äôs race, Coko Beach and Noble Yeats, although the former has had 13 runs over fences. https://t.co/DipEebVIt5

Recent history favours 8 or 9 year olds, who have won the last six renewals in a row, although prior to 2015 the optimum age was between 9 and 11 years old. From 1981 to 2014 this range accounted for all bar six winners (28/34), with only three wins apiece for 8 and 12 year olds. https://t.co/Qld9y3p0vQ

The general rule of thumb has always been that you need a horse with enough experience to cope with the unique demands of the National, while those with too many miles on the clock may have their best days behind them. Both novices & veterans have tended to struggle in the race. https://t.co/4OBF3vl9Dm

In the third of my #GrandNational threads this week, we‚Äôll focus on age and experience. Again there‚Äôs evidence of a shift in trends towards younger horses in recent years, which we‚Äôll explore further, but overall these particular stats have been pretty consistent over the years. https://t.co/vlg6cgvIqM

ICYMI earlier: here‚Äôs the second of my threads this week on the #GrandNational, each looking at a different aspect of the race and highlighting how it has changed over the years. Today we take a look at the shifting weight range for winners. https://t.co/H4OnKBTv6j
@Orangefleece Thanks v much‚Ä¶ üëçüèª
@Pilsudski97 Thank you‚Ä¶ üëçüèª

But when it comes to pinpointing the winner of this year‚Äôs race, the usual weight & rating stats go out of the window - so we‚Äôll need to look elsewhere to frame a shortlist. Tomorrow I‚Äôll focus on age and experience, on Thursday we‚Äôll look at stamina and key form races on Friday. https://t.co/pCYKtmF6mC

At the bottom end of the handicap, there are no fewer than 24 runners set to carry between 10st 7lb and 10st 13lb, just a narrow six pound margin. This weight band has accounted for nine of the 21 winners this millennium, with two more on 11st, so it‚Äôs still the optimum range. https://t.co/ZtA5zDnEgk

All bar three Grand National winners since 1984 carried a weight within 15lb of the lowest handicapped horse, making this year‚Äôs renewal one of the most unpredictable in a long time. Many Clouds (21lb higher), Neptune Collonges (20lb) & Tiger Roll (17lb) are the only exceptions. https://t.co/MNQTELK8cf

Realistically, Minella Times is going to struggle on top weight, compared to the 10st 3lb carried last year. Red Rum was the last horse to successfully carry top weight to victory in 1974, although Many Clouds was only a pound off when winning in 2015 under 11st 9lb. https://t.co/k4DyWduzWV

Seven of the first ten in the betting for this year‚Äôs race are in the top 12 of the handicap and set to carry 11st 4lb or more. Significantly, all bar Minella Times & Delta Work are within 15lb of the bottom weight, giving them all a decent chance to defy their handicap mark. https://t.co/GombJ8hzfi

Top weight was reduced to 11st 10lb in 2009 and no horse has run from out of the handicap since 2013. But this year‚Äôs race is very unusual in that it‚Äôs set to feature the highest bottom weight we‚Äôve seen in the race. In effect it‚Äôs a limited handicap, with the lowest on 10st 7lb. https://t.co/MUbcF8Fh8h

When considering weight in the Grand National it has to be in the context of the handicap range. Gone are the days when the top weight would carry a massive 12 stone, while the majority allocated the minimum of 10 stone raced from out of the handicap, not on their true mark. https://t.co/uyJV3BBWoH

Prior to the 2021 renewal, in each of the three previous runnings (2017-19) three of the four places were filled by horses carrying 10st 11lb+. While none of the horses to finish last year‚Äôs race carried more than 10st 13lb, only five runners had 11st or more and all were 25/1+. https://t.co/wqUkl9diRr

The way the race is framed now, with compressed weights and higher quality horses competing, means that conditions actually favour the horses in the top half of the handicap. Eight of the last 12 winners allocated 10st 11lb or more, with an average winning weight of 11st 1lb. https://t.co/t8y7qLn1Si

The four biggest weight carrying performances since Grittar‚Äôs win under 11st 5lb forty years ago have all come in the last 11 years; Don‚Äôt Push It in 2010 (11st 5lb), Neptune Collonges in 2012 (11st 6lb), Many Clouds in 2015 (11st 9lb) and Tiger Roll in 2019 (11st 5lb). https://t.co/68hOdEyIuD

Since then we have seen a major shift, with six of the last 12 winners carrying 11st or more. This is perhaps not surprising; the fences have been softened and the distance reduced, in the interests of horse welfare, making it much easier for the heavy weights to last the trip. https://t.co/iXjLxwsqdz

From 1984 through to 2008 no horse won the Grand National carrying more than 11st 1lb - and all bar two were under 11 stone. This was one of the strongest determining factors when looking for likely winners of the race. You wanted a lightly weighted improving horse with stamina. https://t.co/YCUmEzNlIm

In the second of my #GrandNational threads, I‚Äôll take a closer look at how the weight trends have shifted in the last decade. While horses have generally found it difficult to carry big weights over the marathon distance of the National, this is no longer necessarily the case. https://t.co/Ao6Ohixp6n

With Ireland responsible for nine of the first 11 horses in the betting for the 2022 Grand National it all points to another victory for the Emerald Isle. However, many of the leading contenders are also at the top end of the handicap. So next time we‚Äôll take a look at weight. https://t.co/Zme0dCkSoR

Between them JP McManus and Gigginstown account for 12 of the 40 horses entered in this year‚Äôs race. The famous green and gold colours were carried to victory by Don‚Äôt Push It in 2010, as well as Minella Times last year, while Gigginstown have won three of the last five runnings. https://t.co/nl7b5rA358

Numbersixvalverde‚Äôs trainer Martin Brassil will be hoping for a repeat success with Thyestes Chase winner Longhouse Poet. Other Irish contenders to note include Bobbyjo Chase runner up Escaria Ten, Run Wild Fred and Enjoy D‚ÄôAllen, who was recently purchased by JP McManus. https://t.co/Xzah8EITLD

Two winners of the Irish Grand National have gone on to win at Aintree - Bobbyjo in 1998/99 and Numbersixvalverde in 2005/06, although a number of others have tried and failed to land the double since. Burrows Saint and Freewheelin Dylan will be aiming to emulate them this year. https://t.co/nuQZtEtRiX

Trainer Ted Walsh is also no stranger to Grand National success, having won the race with Papillon in 2000. He went close again with Seabass, third in 2012, as well as Any Second Now, who was arguably unlucky when also third last year and will be hoping to go two places better. https://t.co/0smBDDwe1f

Henry de Bromhead achieved an historic Gold Cup/Grand National 1st & 2nd double last year and will be attempting to repeat that feat. Minella Times carried just 10st 3lb in 2021 and will have to defy top weight of 11st 10lb, something that no horse has done since Red Rum in 1974. https://t.co/Hw8GqrO5sS

Willie Mullins was dominant at the Cheltenham Festival, but he has yet to repeat his victory with Hedgehunter in 2005, despite knocking on the door several times since, with two seconds, two thirds and a fourth place in the last 15 runnings. Burrows Saint is his main hope again. https://t.co/bFVkJsmse8

Gordon Elliott won the race with Silver Birch in 2007 and Tiger Roll in 2018/19 and has gone a similar route with Delta Work, who won the cross country chase at the Cheltenham Festival. Elliott‚Äôs recent form is a worry though, as he‚Äôs only had one win from his last 72 runners. https://t.co/xRjDraeAjJ

Over half of this year‚Äôs field are trained in Ireland: 22 of the 40 declared at the five day stage. This includes eight runners from triple Grand National winner Gordon Elliott, four representatives for Willie Mullins and three for last year‚Äôs winning trainer Henry de Bromhead. https://t.co/MELX4MqFYm

Of the fifteen horses to finish the 2021 Grand National only three were trained in Britain - and only two British trained horses have been placed in the first five in the last three renewals of the race. So it‚Äôs no surprise to see Irish contenders heading the betting once again. https://t.co/rdwL5d8R6B

Not only have the Irish won 10 of the last 22 runnings, giving them an impressive strike rate of 45%, they are now dominating the race completely. They saddled the first four home in 2018, four of the first five in 2019, and an incredible ten of the first 11 finishers last year. https://t.co/sFidSMUqbE

Before Bobbyjo‚Äôs victory in 1999, the Irish had a 24 year barren period, when 121 horses came to Aintree and they all lost. In fact, from 1976 to 1998 only six Irish horses actually finished in the first three places. How times have now changed since the turn of the millennium. https://t.co/VDCO4uJFAj

It‚Äôs easy to forget now, but Aintree wasn‚Äôt always a happy hunting ground for Irish challengers. After the great Vincent O‚ÄôBrien won the race three years in a row with three different horses from 1953 to 1955, L‚ÄôEscargot‚Äôs win in 1975 would be their only other success until 1999. https://t.co/dqLYz6XIFD

Last year Minella Times became the tenth Irish trained Grand National winner since Bobbyjo in 1999. Papillon (2000), Monty‚Äôs Pass (2003), Hedgehunter (2005), Numbersixvalverde (2006), Silver Birch (2007), Rule The World (2016) and Tiger Roll (2018 & 2019) all won this millennium. https://t.co/DIR6YYapYV

There were many memorable moments at this year‚Äôs Academy Awards, all of which deserved celebrating. Yet they were robbed of their moment in the spotlight because of the actions of one individual, who ruined the evening for everyone else. So let‚Äôs now focus on the winners instead.

Finally, Britain‚Äôs own @rizwanahmed made Oscars history by becoming the first Muslim to win an Academy Award, for Live Action Short, after being nominated for Sound of Metal last year. It can only be a matter of time before he wins an acting Oscar too: https://t.co/FwCN9LA0zI

Another wonderful speech came from @ArianaDeBose, winning Best Supporting Actress for West Side Story, becoming only the second Latina actor to win an Oscar after Rita Moreno, who won the award for the same role sixty years ago, back in 1962. https://t.co/WfizwXYTfS

Another speech that was completely overlooked due to the events that preceded it was the one by Questlove, who won Best Documentary for Summer of Soul. This was one of the most uplifting films of the year, so it thoroughly deserved to win this accolade: https://t.co/jAsmEMIBmj

It was great to see @jes_chastain finally win a well-deserved Academy Award for Best Actress on her third attempt. She should have already won the Oscar for Zero Dark Thirty, so it was a shame that her speech didn‚Äôt get the coverage it deserved afterwards: https://t.co/8odeZSEJzP

Long time front runner & favourite to win Best Picture, The Power of the Dog joined a select group of just four other films to notch up a total of 11 losses, matching the unenviable feat achieved by Johnny Belinda, Becket, The Turning Point & The Color Purple, scoring just 1/12. https://t.co/HCc3fikSzm

Jane Campion became only the third woman in Oscars history to win Best Director, following Kathryn Bigelow (The Hurt Locker) and Chloe Zhao (Nomadland). But her film, The Power of the Dog, was the first in 54 years to win Director only. This has only happened on eight occasions.

CODA won all three categories it was nominated for, becoming the first film to win Best Picture with fewer than four nominations in 90 years (since 1932) and the first in Oscars history to go 3/3. It was also the first film to win without both a Director and Editing nomination. https://t.co/PEI5Snu327

CODA‚Äôs writer/director @sianheder won Best Adapted Screenplay, becoming only the third female to win this award with a solo credit, after Ruth Prawer Jhabvala (A Room with a View, Howard‚Äôs End) & Emma Thompson (Sense and Sensibility). Only 18 women have ever won a writing Oscar.

First, @TroyKotsur, who became the first male deaf actor to win an Academy Award, following in the footsteps of his CODA co-star, @MarleeMatlin, who won an Oscar for her role in Children of a Lesser God in 1986. This was my favourite speech of the night: https://t.co/wpTH1IFxjq

Christian Williams is proving to be a master of staying chases, saddling the 1st & 2nd in the Scottish National. Although it didn‚Äôt strictly fit the trends on 11st 5lb, Robert James took a valuable 7lb off, so another winner under 11st. Win My Wings lands the Eider / SN double. https://t.co/O65ewM0yPw

@NJHag Yes, the race is just unrecognisable now. It‚Äôs not the same at all. I‚Äôll still be posting my thoughts on here, but with the likely bottom weight set to be 10st 8lb you might as well throw the stats and trends out of the window!

It says everything you need to know about the changing nature of the Grand National that the top weight in this year‚Äôs Scottish National wouldn‚Äôt even get a run. In fact 18 above Hill Sixteen would to come out. There are more stayers running at Ayr than there will be at Aintree.

Taking all factors into account, my own personal long list would include:

Win My Wings
The Wolf
Stormy Judge
Via Dolorosa
Major Dundee
The Ferry Master
El Paso Wood
Cool Mix

But also don‚Äôt discount four times course winner Strong Economy to run a big race at 100/1+!

Chirico Vallis - 3rd Classic Chase, 3m 5f
Innisfree Lad - 3rd Eider Chase, 4m 1.5f
Court Master - 4th Eider Chase, 4m 1.5f
Ferry Master - 4th Scottish National, 4m
El Paso Wood - 4th Midlands National, 4m 2f
Cool Mix - 5th in Scottish National, 4m
Strong Economy - won 3m 3f

Best staying form:

Hill Sixteen - 2nd Becher Chase, 3m 2f
Vintage Clouds - 3rd Scottish National, 4m
Kitty‚Äôs Light - 2nd Bet365 Gold Cup, 3m 5f
Jersey Bean - won 3m 4.5f
Win My Wings - won Eider Chase, 4m 1.5f
The Wolf - 2nd 3m 7.5f
Prime Venture - 4th Midlands & Welsh National

So focusing on those carrying under 11 stone, aged 10 or under, that have won over 3m+, we are left with the following group of five horses:

One More Fleurie
Major Dundee
History of Fashion
El Paso Wood
Strong Economy

The Ferry Master and Cool Mix were also 4th & 5th last year.

In the Scottish National the most important consideration is stamina. All bar three winners had won over 3m, 18/24 won over further than 3m, 17/24 had run in race over a distance of at least 3m 4f+. So proven staying power is still a key factor when looking for the likely winner.

Scottish National tends to favour the younger horses. Since the race was first run at Ayr in 1966 48/55 horses have been aged between 7 and 10. Only 1 x 6yo, 5 x 11yo, 1 x 12yo, although three of those aged eleven have won the race since 2009: Hello Bud, Merigo & Wayward Prince.

Generally it is those at the lower end of the handicap that fare best in this race, with 45 of the last 50 winners carrying 11-03 or less. In fact all bar ten were on 11st or less and all bar 12 were carrying 10-12 or less. So it does pay to focus on those in the bottom half.

While recent history has seen more success at the top end of the handicap, only dual winner Vincente has carried more than 11st 3lb to victory since 2004. He is one of five top weights have won the race in the last 30 years; Run For Free, Belmont King, Young Kenny & Grey Abbey.

Scottish National trends: Since Red Rum won the race in 1974 only nine horses have carried over 11 stone to victory, although this includes seven winners in the last 22 years. Even more notably, 29/51 winners since 1970 carried 10-02 or less to victory, including 9 of last 16.

The Midlands Grand National continues to be one of the strongest trends races in the calendar: 17/20 winners since 2000 have qualified on all of the key weight, age and stamina criteria. #MGN2022 https://t.co/QV6AIGruBp

This is an excellent piece, putting the Ukraine war in its proper historical context. The world order is changing again, just as it did in 1989. We can only hope and pray that there is a similar positive outcome eventually this time. https://t.co/AiGw5vOEqL

Final Nudge, Screaming Colours and Achille were third, fourth and sixth in this race last year, so cannot be discounted, but they are up against it on the age trend now, at 13, 10 and 12 years old respectively. But their stamina will again come to the fore on soft ground.

Other horses to qualify on all of the trends, but yet to win over further than 3m, are as follows:

Padleyourowncanoe
Young Dev
De Young Warrior

All of the remaining contenders are either too high in the weights (carrying over 11st) or too old (10yo+) so they fail to qualify.

Both El Paso Wood and Gwencily Berbas are trained by David Pipe, who won this race four years in a row from 2011 to 2014, achieving that feat with four different horses. Jonjo O‚ÄôNeil has won this  race on two occasions, in 2010 and 2021, while Evan Williams also won in 2016.

Time To Get Up won this race last year and has a great chance to repeat that success, while Captain Drake finished runner up two years ago and won the Devon National last time out. El Paso Wood won the Somerset National earlier this season over a mile shorter distance than this.

Here are the best pieces of winning form over further than 3m 2f in this year‚Äôs MGN for horses that also qualify on the trends for weight and age:

Time To Get Up, 4m 2f
Captain Drake, 3m 6f
Gwencily Berbas, 3m 6f
Supreme Escape, 3m 6f
El Paso Wood, 3m 2f

#MGN2022

The final factor, and arguably the most important, is of course stamina. Every winner of the Midlands Grand National since 1997 had previously won over 3m, all bar two of them over fences. Ideally you also want form in races over further. #MGN2022

The other important factor in the Midlands Grand National is age: Regal Flow bucked the trend by winning as an 11yo in 2018, but otherwise no winner since 1995 has been older than nine. So you basically need a young, unexposed horse on a light weight to win. #MGN2022

Midlands Grand National trends: since Bonanza Boy won under 11-10 in 1992 there have been only four winners of the race to carry over 11st to victory. 24/28 winners in the last 30 years have been allotted 10st 12lb or less. #MGN2022

@jamesaknight @gamray No, but it also follows his usual playbook. If the initial ground invasion fails in the first few days, as this has done, he will just shell and bombard civilian areas in order to obliterate them out of existence. We have seen it before in Aleppo and Grozny.
@jamesaknight @gamray We can only hope. Just as we can only hope and pray that we don‚Äôt wait until it‚Äôs too late before we take action too.

@jamesaknight @gamray Fair enough. I understand these things are difficult, it‚Äôs an impossible situation. But I don‚Äôt think nuclear threat should make it unprecedented. If we are prepared to act beyond those red lines then we should act now, in my view.
@gamray @jamesaknight All the more reason why NATO should stand with Ukraine in my opinion, rather than hide behind their own defences.
@jamesaknight @gamray It will take a long time before that takes effect on Putin himself. And the one thing Ukrainians do not have the luxury of is time.
@jamesaknight @gamray My question wasn‚Äôt rhetorical, or aimed at NATO: genuinely, where do YOU draw the line? Do we just hide behind NATO, saying ‚Äúwe‚Äôre alright Jack‚Äù?!
@jamesaknight @gamray Yes, exactly: in their own self interest.

@gamray @jamesaknight I‚Äôm certainly not glamorising it. Far from it. And I‚Äôm a pacifist not a warmonger. But history teaches us that failing to act rarely resolved the situation; it‚Äôs only going to get worse.

@jamesaknight @gamray I don‚Äôt think so. Where next? What if it‚Äôs Estonia after Ukraine? Or Poland? Where do you draw the line? Boundaries cease to matter in such instances, it‚Äôs about humanity. We are all Ukrainians in these circumstances.
@jamesaknight @gamray That‚Äôs the point: history shows us that it will only ever get worse before it gets better. And it only gets better if good people are prepared to make a stand against tyranny.

@gamray @jamesaknight I try not to be emotional about these things, but it‚Äôs impossible not to empathise. As human beings we need to stand united with Ukraine rather than be thankful we can hide behind our own nuclear deterrent. In such circumstances we are global citizens, borders become meaningless.

@jamesaknight The media likes to paint Putin to be a madman, but he‚Äôs not stupid. He‚Äôs not going to escalate to a world war that he cannot win. He would effectively be signing Russia‚Äôs own death warrant and annihilation. A NFZ is the first and most important step in forcing him to back down.

@gamray @jamesaknight Again, that is quite a leap and assumption to make. Failing to act is a failure of humanity. Makes no difference whether or not Ukraine are part of NATO. Humanity should dictate that we stand united with them against invasion. Self interest is no justification whatsoever.

@jamesaknight No, I‚Äôm making no such concession. I am saying that NATO‚Äôs nuclear arsenal is supposed to provide a deterrent against an attack. It is wholly wrong to make assumptions that this is what Putin will do, it just sounds like a pretty lame excuse for not intervening.

@jamesaknight Failing to act sounds like self interest, to be honest. We have stood by and seen mass genocides in Darfur, Rwanda, Bosnia, Syria. All in the last 30 years. This is what happens when the world fails to take action. Dictators and despots know they can act with impunity.

@jamesaknight That is why we are supposed to have a nuclear deterrent, otherwise what is the point? Such a war will only ever be started by a ruthless dictator with no regard for human life. And that is exactly why he has to be stopped. Sanctions are not enough.
